text: Resolution adopted by the Economic and Social Council on 24 July 2013
[on the recommendation of the Statistical Commission (E/2013/24)]
2013/21.	Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics
The Economic and Social Council,
Recalling recent resolutions of the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council highlighting the fundamental importance of official statistics for the national and global development agenda,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* recent resolutions of the {{General Assembly}} and the {{Economic and Social Council}} highlighting the fundamental importance of official statistics for the national and global development agenda,

text: Bearing in mind the critical role of high-quality official statistical information in analysis and informed policy decision-making in support of sustainable development, peace and security, as well as for mutual knowledge and trade among the States and peoples of an increasingly connected world, demanding openness and transparency,
textWithHighlights: *Bearing in mind* the critical role of high-quality official statistical information in analysis and informed policy decision-making in support of sustainable development, peace and security, as well as for mutual knowledge and trade among the States and peoples of an increasingly connected world, demanding openness and transparency,

text: Bearing in mind also that the essential trust of the public in the integrity of official statistical systems and its confidence in statistics depend to a large extent on respect for the fundamental values and principles that are the basis of any society seeking to understand itself and to respect the rights of its members and, in this context, that the professional independence and accountability of statistical agencies are crucial,
textWithHighlights: *Bearing in mind* also that the essential trust of the public in the integrity of official statistical systems and its confidence in statistics depend to a large extent on respect for the fundamental values and principles that are the basis of any society seeking to understand itself and to respect the rights of its members and, in this context, that the professional independence and accountability of statistical agencies are crucial,

text: Stressing that, in order to be effective, the fundamental values and principles that govern statistical work have to be guaranteed by legal and institutional frameworks and respected at all political levels and by all stakeholders in national statistical systems,
textWithHighlights: *Stressing* that, in order to be effective, the fundamental values and principles that govern statistical work have to be guaranteed by legal and institutional frameworks and respected at all political levels and by all stakeholders in national statistical systems,

text: Endorses the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, set out below as adopted by the Statistical Commission in 1994 and reaffirmed in 2013, and recommends them to the General Assembly for endorsement:

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: endorsement of the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics

textWithHighlights: *Endorses* the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, set out below as adopted by the {{Statistical Commission}} in 1994 and reaffirmed in 2013, and *recommends* them to the <<General Assembly>> for [[endorsement]]:
uncertainties: Classifying the deliverable type for GA’s endorsement could be seen as either “policy” or “standards”; selected “standards” given the nature of the Fundamental Principles. Also, for the deciding verb “Endorses”, ECOSOC could be considered the implicit assignee, but it is left empty as the action is performed by the Council itself.

text: Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics

Principle 1. Official statistics provide an indispensable element in the information system of a democratic society, serving the Government, the economy and the public with data about the economic, demographic, social and environmental situation. To this end, official statistics that meet the test of practical utility are to be compiled and made available on an impartial basis by official statistical agencies to honour citizens’ entitlement to public information.
textWithHighlights: Principle 1. Official statistics provide an indispensable element in the information system of a democratic society, serving the Government, the economy and the public with data about the economic, demographic, social and environmental situation. To this end, official statistics that meet the test of practical utility are to be [[compiled]] and [[made available]] on an impartial basis by <<official statistical agencies>> to honour citizens’ entitlement to public information.
uncertainties: This paragraph is part of endorsed principles rather than an operative directive; operative verb is absent. Assignee and deliverables are inferred from the prescriptive phrasing (“are to be ... by official statistical agencies”). The deliverable type for “compiled” is approximated as “analysis” due to limited category options.

text: Principle 2. To retain trust in official statistics, the statistical agencies need to decide according to strictly professional considerations, including scientific principles and professional ethics, on the methods and procedures for the collection, processing, storage and presentation of statistical data.
textWithHighlights: Principle 2. To retain trust in official statistics, the statistical agencies need to decide according to strictly professional considerations, including scientific principles and professional ethics, on the methods and procedures for the collection, processing, storage and presentation of statistical data.
uncertainties: This is a principles paragraph within an endorsed framework, not an operative directive by ECOSOC; therefore no operative verb, assignee, or deliverable extracted.

text: Principle 3. To facilitate a correct interpretation of the data, the statistical agencies are to present information according to scientific standards on the sources, methods and procedures of the statistics.

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Present information according to scientific standards

textWithHighlights: Principle 3. To facilitate a correct interpretation of the data, the <<statistical agencies>> are to [[present information]] according to scientific standards on the sources, methods and procedures of the statistics.
uncertainties: This paragraph is part of the endorsed principles rather than a direct operative directive of ECOSOC; "are to present" is prescriptive but not an operative verb from the provided list, so action_verb is set to null. Assignee "statistical agencies" is categorized as 'other' since there is no specific entity category for national statistical agencies. The deliverable is interpreted as information sharing rather than standards, as the core action is to present information.

text: Principle 4. The statistical agencies are entitled to comment on erroneous interpretation and misuse of statistics.
textWithHighlights: Principle 4. The {{statistical agencies}} are entitled to comment on erroneous interpretation and misuse of statistics.

text: Principle 5. Data for statistical purposes may be drawn from all types of sources, be they statistical surveys or administrative records. Statistical agencies are to choose the source with regard to quality, timeliness, costs and the burden on respondents.
textWithHighlights: Principle 5. Data for statistical purposes may be drawn from all types of sources, be they statistical surveys or administrative records. <<Statistical agencies>> are to choose the source with regard to quality, timeliness, costs and the burden on respondents.
uncertainties: This paragraph states a principle rather than using a formal operative verb; no concrete deliverable is specified. Treated "Statistical agencies" as an assignee despite the lack of a directive verb.

text: Principle 6. Individual data collected by statistical agencies for statistical compilation, whether they refer to natural or legal persons, are to be strictly confidential and used exclusively for statistical purposes.

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Exclusive statistical use of individual data

textWithHighlights: Principle 6. Individual data collected by {{statistical agencies}} for statistical compilation, whether they refer to natural or legal persons, are to be [[strictly confidential]] and [[used exclusively for statistical purposes]].
uncertainties: No explicit operative verb; treated as articulation of standards without assignees.

text: Principle 7. The laws, regulations and measures under which the statistical systems operate are to be made public.

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: publication of laws, regulations and measures

textWithHighlights: Principle 7. The laws, regulations and measures under which the statistical systems operate are to be [[made public]].
uncertainties: No explicit operative verb or assignee is given; treated as a deliverable (information sharing) without specifying who must carry it out.

text: Principle 8. Coordination among statistical agencies within countries is essential to achieve consistency and efficiency in the statistical system.
textWithHighlights: Principle 8. Coordination among statistical agencies within countries is essential to achieve consistency and efficiency in the statistical system.

text: Principle 9. The use by statistical agencies in each country of international concepts, classifications and methods promotes the consistency and efficiency of statistical systems at all official levels.
textWithHighlights: Principle 9. The use by statistical agencies in each country of international concepts, classifications and methods promotes the consistency and efficiency of statistical systems at all official levels.

text: Principle 10. Bilateral and multilateral cooperation in statistics contributes to the improvement of systems of official statistics in all countries.
textWithHighlights: Principle 10. Bilateral and multilateral cooperation in statistics contributes to the improvement of systems of official statistics in all countries.
uncertainties: No operative verb, assignee, or deliverable detected; this sentence states a general principle rather than a procedural action.
